title: Grubhub earnings send shares tumbling over 40 per cent
text:
The food-delivery platform reported revenues of US$322.1 million, shy of analyst estimates by more than US$7 million, and revised its fourth-quarter guidance to between US$315 million and US$335 million, well below the expected US$388 million. Orders dipped 15 per cent from the same period last year. (The Logic, CNBC)

Talking point: Grubhub—now in third place in the U.S. with a 23 per cent market share—is losing customers to Uber Eats and DoorDash, at 25 per cent and 35 per cent market share, respectively. Though it’s the only major U.S. player currently turning a profit, it’s become less profitable over the past two years thanks in part to a dramatic increase in spending on promotions. Unlike Uber and DoorDash, Grubhub features primarily small- and medium-sized independent restaurants in exclusive partnerships with the platform, but the firm said it will now branch out from that strategy to broaden its network and attract new diners. CEO Matt Maloney has described the food-on-demand industry as a “weird bubble that is about to burst,” adding that it’s getting more difficult to raise funds as private investors become wary of high-profile startup failures like WeWork.
